questions.question: Question 1: Moll glands are examples of
questions.explanation:
Moll glands are examples of apocrine sweat gland. Moll glands are present in the eyelid. They are a type of modified apocrine sweat glands opening 
either into a lash follicle or directly onto the anterior lid margin between the lashes. Zeis glands are a type of modified sebaceous glands associated with lash follicles. Meibomian 
glands are modified sebaceous glands found in the tarsal plates.

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient presented with a painless swelling and watering in his left eye. Examination 
revealed the following finding. Which of the following statements is false regarding his 
diagnosis?

options.a: It needs to be surgically treated.
options.c: It does not have malignant potential.
options.d: It is a chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation.

questions.explanation:
A painless swelling on the lower lid is suggestive of a chalazion (tarsal cyst/meibomian cyst). It has 
the malignant potential to become an adenocarcinoma of the meibomian gland. Chalazion is the chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation (option D) of the meibomian gland 
(option B). It presents as painless swelling of the eyelid. It is more common in adults than 
children. Treatment includes incision and curettage (option B) and intralesional injection of 
triamcinolone acetate. 396 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question:
Question 3: A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude the 
possibility of  
.
questions.explanation:
A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude the 
possibility of sebaceous gland carcinoma. Note: A chalazion can undergo malignant change into sebaceous gland carcinoma 
(adenocarcinoma of meibomian gland). Recurrences of chalazia are not uncommon. However, the physician should entertain the 
possibility of malignancy in such cases and should biopsy a lesion that recurs or appears atypical. 
The pathologist should be alerted to the suspicion of sebaceous gland carcinoma and frozen 
sections and lipid stains should be requested.

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient presented to the clinic with severe left eye pain, watering, and swelling of the lid for 
2 days. He says it's difficult to see the laptop screen while working and he is unable to 
complete his daily targets. On examination, tender swelling is noted as shown below. What is 
the cause of this finding?
questions.explanation:
The patient has acute presentation and painful swelling in the palpebral conjunctiva as shown in 
the image, suggestive of internal hordeolum. It is an acute suppurative inflammation of the 
meibomian gland associated with blockage of the duct. Other options: Options A and B: Hordeolum externum or stye is the acute staphylococcal infection of the hair 
follicle/Zeis gland/Moll gland. Option D: Chalazion is a chronic non-suppurative lipogranulomatous inflammation of the 
Meibomian gland. 397 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question:
Question 5: What is the length of the nasolacrimal duct? 390 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The nasolacrimal duct is 12–18 mm long. The lacrimal drainage system consists of the lacrimal sac, which is 10–12 mm long. It lies in the 
lacrimal fossa, between the anterior and posterior lacrimal crests. The lacrimal bone and the 
frontal process of the maxilla separate the lacrimal sac from the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. The nasolacrimal duct is the inferior continuation of the lacrimal sac. It is 12–18 mm long and is 
directed downwards, backward, and laterally. The opening of the duct into the inferior meatus is 
partially covered by a mucosal fold (valve of Hasner). The puncta are openings on the lid margin. There are two canaliculi from the puncta. Each 
canaliculus (superior and inferior) has two parts: Vertical (2 mm) and horizontal (8 mm). The 
superior and inferior canaliculi usually unite to form the common canaliculus, which opens into 
the lateral wall of the lacrimal sac. A small flap of mucosa (Rosenmüller valve) overhangs the 
junction of the common canaliculus and the lacrimal sac and prevents the reflux of tears into the 
canaliculi. The image below shows structures of the lacrimal apparatus. 398 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question: Question 6: Where does the nasolacrimal duct open?
questions.explanation:
The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus. The nasolacrimal duct is the inferior continuation of the lacrimal sac. It is 12–18 mm long and is 
directed downwards, backward, and laterally. The opening of the duct into the inferior meatus is 
partially covered by a mucosal fold, called the valve of Hasner. The valve of Hasner prevents 
reflux from the nose.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question:
Question 7: A 60-year-old woman came for an eye exam due to a gritty sensation that has been causing 
her a lot of discomfort. On examination, Rose Bengal staining is positive. She is diagnosed 
with keratoconjunctivitis sicca. Which of the following layer of the tear film is deficient in this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is due to the deficiency of the aqueous layer of the tear film. In keratoconjunctivitis sicca, patients present with irritation and foreign body sensation. Marginal 
tear strip is reduced. The conjunctiva become dry and lustreless with positive Rose Bengal 
staining. Causes of keratoconjunctivitis sicca: • Sjogren's syndrome (primary keratoconjunctivitis sicca) • Non-Sjogren's keratoconjunctivitis sicca • Primary age-related hyposecretion (most common) • Lacrimal gland deficiencies - congenital, infiltration by tumors or sarcoidosis, surgical removal • Lacrimal gland duct obstruction - old trachoma, burns, SJS • Reflex hyposecretion (neurogenic causes) - Parkinson disease, 7th nerve palsy, reflex sensory 
block 399 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following statements is true regarding the phenol red test for dry eye?

options.b: It measures tear production based on the length of colour change in the thread
options.c: If color changes to blue, it depicts mucin deficiency.

questions.explanation:
Phenol red test measures the tear production according to the length of colour change in the 
thread. In phenol red test, the alkalinity of tears changes its colour to bright orange on contact. It doesn't 
require anaesthesia (unlike Schirmer's test). Three millimetres of a fine dye-impregnated 75-mm 
cotton thread is placed under the lateral one-fifth of the inferior palpebral lid margin for 15 
seconds. Based on length of colour change, • >20 mm - normal tear production • 10 to 19 mm - borderline dry eye • <10 mm - severe dry eye
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question:
Question 9: 391 
Sold by @itachibot Identify the test shown below.
questions.explanation:
The image shows a tear strip placed in the lower lid of the eye. This is the Schirmer test which is 
used to check for dry eye. Dry eye is a multifactorial disease of the eye characterised by loss of homeostasis of the tear film. 
Patients present with irritation, foreign body sensation and dryness. Treatment of dry eye 
includes medical treatment (lubricating eyedrops, most commonly methylcellulose derivatives) or 
surgical treatment (lacrimal punctum occlusion using silicone plugs). Other tests for dry eye include: • Tear film break-up test is used to determine the interval between a complete blink and 
appearance of first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. A drop of fluorescein is instilled 
in the eye, following by examination in the cobalt-blue light of a slit-lamp. • Rose Bengal staining is used for the detection of dry, dead epithelium in dry eye. • Tear osmolarity test is performed with an osmometer. Other options: Option B: Ishihara plates are used to test colour vision. They help detect red-green colour 
blindness. Option C: Jones test is used in watering eye. It uses fluorescein dye. Option D: Goldmann's tonometry is used to measure intra-ocular pressure. It consists of a double 
prism mounted on a slit-lamp.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question:
Question 10: You are conducting retrospective research on factors responsible for dry eye disorder. As a 
part of your study, you are looking through the files in the clinic of dry eye patients. Which 
among the following patients would not be included in your study?

options.a: A 26 year old patient showing decreased levels of lactoferrin in tear samples
options.b: A 20 year old patient showing tear film break up at 18-20 seconds
options.c: A 24 year old patient showing A pattern stain in Rose bengal staining
options.d: A 22 year old patient showing Schirmer test tear strip wet upto 9 mm

questions.explanation:
A patient with tear film break up at 18-20 seconds is considered to be normal. All the other 
patients have dry eye. 400 
Sold by @itachibot Tear film break-up (BUT) time is the interval between a complete blink and the appearance of a 
first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. It is an indicator of the adequacy of the mucin 
component of tears. Inference: • 15-35 seconds - normal • < 10 seconds- unstable tear film Other options: Option A: Tear samples can be assayed for the presence of markers known to be decreased (e.g. 
lactoferrin) or elevated (e.g. matrix metalloproteinase-9) in dry eye. This is known as tear 
constituent measurement. Option C: A patient with A pattern on Rose Bengal staining has severe dry eye. Option D: A patient with 9mm wet Schirmer strip has moderate dry eye.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question:
Question 11: The findings of a test done in a patient under evaluation for dry eye are shown below. Identify 
the test. 392 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image above depicts lacrimal scintigraphy. Lacrimal scintigraphy (dacryoscintigraphy) is used to assess the lacrimal drainage function. A 
radioactive tracer (technetium-99m) is instilled into the conjunctival sac. Its path is then 
visualised with an Anger gamma camera. It is useful for the evaulation of watering eye. Other tests for evaluation of watering eye include regurgitation test, syringing, fluorescein dye 
disappearance test (FDDT), Jones dye test and dacryocystography. Other options: Option A: In regurgitation test, steady pressure with the index finger is applied above the medial 
palpebral ligament. Option B: In dacryocystography, a radioopaque material is inserted into the lacrimal sac, 
following which X-rays are taken. Option C: The image shows the Jones dye test. 401 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question: Question 12: What is the site of blockage in congenital dacryocystitis?
questions.explanation:
The site of blockage in congenital dacryocystitis is the nasolacrimal duct. Congenital dacryocystitis occurs due to the stasis of secretions in the lacrimal sac due to 
congenital blockage in the nasolacrimal duct. Membranous occlusion at its lower end near the 
valve of Hasner is the commonest cause. The image below shows a neonate with congenital dacryocystitis.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question:
Question 13: A mother noticed the following finding in her 3-month-old child. There is a history of 
watering and discharge from his right eye since birth. Which of the following is the best next 
step in the treatment? 393 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
402 
Sold by @itachibot The image showing right-sided swelling in the lacrimal sac area along with watering of the eye is 
suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis. Treatment for a 3-month-old child includes sac massage 
with topical antibiotics. Congenital dacryocystitis is chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac in newborn infants. It occurs 
due to congenital blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. More than 90% of patients with undergo 
spontaneous resolution by 1 year of age. Treatment of congenital dacryocystitis depends on the age of the child: • Less than 9 months: Massaging (Crigler’s massage which increases the hydrostatic pressure 
within the sac) and antibiotic eye drops • 9 months to 4 years: Probing • Older children (> 4 years): Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) gives the best result. In 
DCR, an opening is made into the nasal cavity from the lacrimal sac.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question:
Question 14: A 60-year-old man presents with watering from the right eye for 1 year. Syringing revealed a 
patent drainage system. Rest of the ocular examination was normal. A provisional diagnosis 
of lacrimal pump failure was made. Which of the following test will help in the confirmation 
of the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Lacrimal pump failure can be confirmed with dacryoscintigraphy. Lacrimal pump failure means an inability of the lid muscles to push tears towards the punctum 
for drainage. It is also called functional obstruction and may be secondary to lower lid laxity or 
orbicularis muscle weakness (eg. facial nerve palsy. It is confirmed by dacryoscintigraphy, in 
which a radioactive tracer (technetium-99m) is instilled into the conjunctival sac and its path 
visualised with an Anger gamma camera. An atonic lacrimal sac is seen. Note: In cases of partial obstruction of the lacrimal apparatus, forced injection of fluid into the 
canalicular system (dacryocystography) can overcome the obstruction sites and point to a 
diagnosis of lacrimal pump failure. Thus, dacryoscintigraphy is better for the confirmation of 
lacrimal pump failure.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question:
Question 15: A 55-year-old woman is being counseled for surgery for her long-standing dacryocystitis. 
Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.explanation:
The treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) DCR involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac 
with the lateral nasal mucosa. It re-establishes the lacrimal drainage and is hence the preferred 
surgery for chronic darcyocystectomy. Chronic dacryocystitis is a long-standing inflammation of the lacrimal sac. Streptococcus 
hemolyticus and Staphylococcus aureus are the most common etiological agents. Initial treatment 
is with antibiotics and anti-inflammatory agents. Sequelae include lacrimal fistula formation and 
mucocele formation, which when infected, leads to pyocele formation and finally lacrimal fibrosis. 
Treatment of lacrimal sac fibrosis is dacryocystectomy. Treatment of lacrimal fistula is 
dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR). 403 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient with chronic dacryocystitis, refractory to the medical treatment, has been scheduled 
for dacryocystorhinostomy. Following the surgery, the sac would be draining into the 
 
.
questions.explanation:
After dacryocystorhinostomy, the lacrimal sac drains into the middle meatus. Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal 
sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. This allows tears to drain directly 
from the sac via a new low-resistance pathway into the middle meatus.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question: Question 17: What is the most common ocular manifestation in mumps?
questions.explanation:
The most common ocular manifestation in mumps is dacryocystadenitis. Dacryocystadenitis, or inflammation of the lacrimal gland, is seen in mumps. It presents as a 
painful swelling in the lateral part of the upper lid.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of t

questions.question: Question 18: Which is the most common lacrimal gland tumor?
questions.explanation:
Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor. It is also the most common 
epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland. Pleomorphic adenoma, or benign mixed tumor, presents commonly in middle age as a slowly 
progressive painless swelling in the upper outer quadrant of the eyelid. The bone is usually not 
invaded in these tumors. They are treated by surgical removal along with their intact 
pseudo-capsule. Malignant tumors of the lacrimal gland such as adenoid cystic carcinoma (option A), 
mucoepidermoid carcinoma (option C) and malignant mixed tumor (option D) generally occur in 
the elderly with a short history of appearance, rapid progression and pain. These tumors also 
present in the upper eyelid and are known to invade the adjacent bones. Radical surgical 
procedures and high dose radiotherapy are necessary for the removal of the tumor. Adenoid cystic 
carcinoma is the most common malignant epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland. Both malignant and benign tumors are known to push the eyeball downwards and inwards while 
restricting the upwards and outwards movement of the eyeball. The most common epithelial tumors, in order of frequency, are as follows: • Benign mixed tumor (BMT), also known as a pleomorphic adenoma (PA) • Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) • Pleomorphic adenocarcinoma (ACA) • Mucoepidermoid carcinoma 404 
Sold by @itachibot Orbit Anatomy and Ocular Injuries
